question: In adult men, does daily supplementation with 400 mg of alpha-tocopheryl acetate (vitamin E) reduce the incidence of prostate cancer compared with placebo? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Compared with placebo, vitamin E had no effect on the incidence of prostate cancer (active and placebo vitamin E groups, 9.1 and 9.5 events per 1000 person-years; hazard ratio [HR], 0.97; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.85-1.09; P = .58).
content.source_2: In a double-blind, randomized prevention trial administering 400 mg/day of all-rac-α-tocopheryl acetate, prostate cancer incidence was significantly lower than with placebo (HR 0.84; 95% CI, 0.73–0.97; P=0.02) over a median 8.0-year follow-up.
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS In this large, long-term trial of male physicians, neither vitamin E nor C supplementation reduced the risk of prostate or total cancer.
content.source_4: Preplanned age-stratified analyses indicated that men aged 65 years and older receiving 400 mg α-tocopheryl acetate every other day had a reduced risk of biopsy-confirmed prostate cancer (incidence rate ratio 0.86; 95% CI, 0.75–0.99), whereas no effect was seen in younger participants.
